CHEM 136L is a course that introduces students to the fundamentals of laboratory practice, by guiding them through ten experiments that focus on different lab skills. Through this course, I got acquainted to common lab practices and learned the basic principles of empirical practice of chemistry. As a person with minimal lab experience, this course helped me gain an understanding of the workings of a lab and introduced to the use of basic equipment and practices.Through the experiments I learned to pay attention to detail -- even to an extreme amount at times -- and learned how to utilize the data I collected to understand the chemical processes that we were studying. This semester's course acted as a continuation of the knowledge that I acquired during CHEM 134L and built upon the concepts that I had learned in the fall furthering my knowledge of laboratory practices in chemistry.
I learned a lot about how to work in a lab and to be efficient yet thorough.

I gained a better understanding of the topics we were going over in the lecture course. In addition, I became more comfortable with a variety of lab techniques and practices, including writing a lab notebook, titration and using a spectrometer. It also gave me a practical understanding of the subjects learned in the lecture because I could observe the real-world effects of the concepts I had learned in class.
This course should not be worth 0.5 credits. It is a lot of work. I found that I learned how to work efficiently.

This was a really dreadful course. I often felt like Dr. G was trying to inflict the maximum amount of suffering onto the student simply because he could. Like do we really need to do  a titration three times to know how to do a titration? Because we were often graded on accuracy of our experimental data, this led to considerable stress. How can we be expected to be precise and accurate with a new procedure we've never done before? 

Grading for lab reports can often seem like you're trying to please Gordon Ramsay in Hell's Kitchen.

Strengths of this course include a passionate instructor and fun and engaging labs.

Weaknesses of this course include the quizzes which seem unreasonably hard and unfair as well as the random grading produced by the many different TA graders.

One of the weaknesses of the course is that I felt like I was going through the motions and plugging in data points into a calculator and not understanding the chemistry that I was actually doing. Also, I thought that the prelab quizzes were way too hard, and very few people would actually finish their quiz on time.

The lab reports and grading rubrics are very harsh and not really reviewed and/or relevant to learning actual chemistry; significant figures are also done out of convention which leaves many students confused and essentially disregards worldwide conventions for scientific practices, damaging impressions of STEM in higher education for many students. It could be improved by making the lab report purposes clearer, as that is where most points lost on lab reports are.

Strengths - hands-on approach; well-explained and informative prelab lectures 
Weaknesses - a huge workload for a half-credit course

The strength of the course was the fact that what we covered in Gen Chem Lab was also being covered in Gen Chem 165, so I really understood the experiments I was conducting. I cannot think of any weaknesses.

Strengths: Good exposure to the lab, materials, safety, and how to conduct experiments.
Cons: Heavy load for a 0.5 credit course.

The course is a good survey to general chemistry laboratory techniques. It could be improved by making the experiments less redundant (there was about too much overlap this year) and having the lab reports graded more consistently and having expectations about reports communicated more clearly. Sometimes TAs take off points for things, other times they ignore these same mistakes.
Some of the lab reports were unnecessarily long for a 0.5 credit. I mean this with every ounce of my body... LABS SHOULD NOT BE WORTH ONLY HALF A CREDIT!
The actual content of the course is valuable, however the way things are graded are nit-picky and don't help the students learn the actual concepts

Strengths: the concepts in class reinforce some of the material taught in gen chem lecture.

Weaknesses: the length (4 hours for 1/2 credit) is ridiculous, the lab reports are tedious, and the grading is absurd. You can understand a lab extremely well and still perform poorly on the lab report because you made one significant figure error, which in turn causes more significant figure errors down the road (because apparently consistency means nothing). It's like the instructor knows that everyone taking the course is only doing so for major / premed requirements, and while gen chem lab is universally considered an easier, lighter class (as you'd expect for half a credit), it's the opposite here.

Not only that, but the instructor curves DOWN. On the first day of class, he said that he was "willing to give everyone A's if everyone did A work." Seems reasonable. Towards the end of the semester, he explains that in order to give a B+ average, everyone above a 95% gets an A, everyone 90-95% gets an A-, and so forth.
Weakness-The professor.

The labs were graded by different people every week, which led to inconsistency among the report grades. One week could be a good grade, and the next you could get five points off for including the same stuff that you did the last week.
everything was pretty good.

This course teaches a lot and is an effective means of learning chemistry and lab techniques. The worst part of the class is the grading, which is unreasonable and poorly reflects actual knowledge of chemistry. Lab reports are graded for unimportant minutiae like the use of key words in the abstract or the size of the graph, and especially significant figures. The class is good, but the grading is extremely bad.
It is definitely a lot of work. Harshly graded, but I feel as though I have a lot of lab experience now.

The prelab lectures and actual experiments are interesting to carry out, and the lab manual prepares you well for the quizzes. The grading was not as harsh as last semester, but there are still nit-picky things in the rubric that should be fixed (like multiple points off for missing one vocab word in the purpose when everything else was included).
This class has an excessive amount of work and did not enhance my learning of chemistry concepts.

Weakness: The requirements of lab reports/feedback is sometimes unclear. 
Strength: It's a requirement for many majors/for premed.
The amount of time required for this class warrant it being worth a full credit. Also the grading should be less about formatting and more about actual knowledge of chemistry.

Strength: Lab helped solidify topics covered in Chem 165.
Weakness: Topics in lab did not chronologically align with what we covered in Chem 165.  The last few labs was based on topics learned near the beginning of the semester.

The greatest strength of the course is that most experiments are direct applications of concepts covered in Chem 165 and so the labs really do help you understand the course concepts more deeply as opposed to being presented with completely new information such that you would have to blindly follow the lab manual, not understanding what you're doing.

The greatest weakness of the course, I would say is that the grading on the lab reports is a bit harsh - they take off so many points for small details that have nothing to do with your comprehension of the lab.

The lab reports for this course were often unclear about their requirements. I received many points off of lab reports for not having specific words in the purpose even though there seemed to be no indication as to what specific words I had to use. I also think that often times some of the questions were worded confusingly. Also, the lab manual pages should probably be updated because there were a lot of last-minute corrections applied to them. For instance, a manual for one experiment mentioned a practical final but this course no longer has that requirement. Aside from that, Dr. G is a very passionate instructor and the experiments were engaging and not too challenging.
Some of the lab reports were excruciatingly longer than others.

Strengths - experience in a lab setting
Weaknesses - kind of irrelevant and repetitive, focused too much on things that aren't really important and not enough on techniques or things you would actually need to know to work in a chemistry lab (we did so many titrations and not much else - it would have been nice to learn other techniques)

they are too strict with the lab reports that it seems that they don't care about our learning but just want o keep us busy. the lab reports don't help us learn anything beyond the lab and lecture, so truly don't see the point to them, or at least why they ask for so much.

Pre-lab lectures are very helpful and informative, but some of the labs are a bit tedious and involve lots of waiting. Also, the grading of the lab reports focus too much on small formatting changes and not on conceptual understanding. This course should really be 1 full credit.
I did learn a lot in the lecture and I liked having some basic lab experience. I do feel that some of the work in the lab reports was tedious and unnecessary.
This course is too heavy a workload for half a credit. I spent almost as many hours or more in lab and on the lab reports as I spent doing work for my 1.5 credit language course.

Strengths: Dr. G's office hours, actually doing the experiments

Weaknesses: Sometimes tedious things we do in lab

A strength of the course was Dr. G's lecture prior to the start of the labs. I found that I often learned or better understood material that he explained in an hour than a week of Chemistry 165 lecture material! A significant weakness I found was the inconsistent grading of lab reports by some of the TAs. In particular I always found that I was losing many points in my introduction/purpose and methods sections of lab report for not including information on the results of the experiment. I made me highly upset to see that I was docked often 2-5 marks for not discussing information relevant to the conclusion/results of the experiment (I mentioned this later in the lab as expected near the results section). I have absolutely no idea as to why I would even need to include results in the PURPOSE of an experiment. Often times people who were graded by other TAs did not lose point for NOT having included information about their results in the purpose either.
I think this course does a good job introducing students to lab work but not in developing themselves into independent scientists. Students operate more like robots and less creatively in the lab.

It's simply too much. It's very repetitive (I probably did twenty titrations in ten weeks) and very punitive. I think the lab reports themselves are ridiculous given they take longer than any homework for a full credit course. Necessary skills are built, but it could be done much more efficiently (ie not four hours worth of lab time) and much less stressfully (ie ten page lab reports due every week).
It's difficult, but it was useful to perfect lab skills and different methods of measuring phenomena.

The lab reports are just super intense and take up a ton of time. This lab specifically is definitely worth more that a half credit... But it made me feel like a potion master so I guess that's worth something... THE QUIZZES SUCK. WORST PART OF MY WEEK EVERY WEEK. But the labs themselves aren't too bad. Expect to stay 'till five every lab day (that way if you get out early it's a gift!).

Strengths: Lab TAs are very patient and kind folks! They answer your questions about the lab procedures that may be confusing, and they're aware that for some of us, this is our first time ever in a chemistry lab setting. And they understand your plight of having to take this course! I also acknowledge that this is like any standard Gen Chem lab course. 

Weaknesses: My upperclassman friends have told me that gen chem lab with Dr.G is a weed out course, and it's true. But it's very sad, because it weeds out people not because it's what real science/lab work looks like; it weeds out people because of the meticulous part of science, and because Dr. G is so unnecessarily strict and hostile, like he's always around only to catch you make mistakes, rather than help you. Yes, factual data is serious, but the way that Dr.G enforces everything is rough intimidating especially for a first-year in college. He always brings up "you can do it because you're Yalies" - that's true, but perhaps we're Yalies because we're open to these new learning opportunities, and trying out Gen Chem lab and being in a lab for the first time and see chemistry in action is why we're here. But Dr.G's way of teaching is too rigid to make us feel like we can ever improve. I spend hours preparing for lab because I'm so afraid of what will happen if I mess up one thing in lab; I can't imagine Dr.G helping me, only that he'll point out my mistakes. It doesn't feel like making mistakes is allowed here given that we need to get good grades on our lab reports and the rubric is so harsh.

Overall, GenChem lab this semester was a very negative experience. There is a lack of communication between Dr. G, the TFs and the students, and the lab quizzes were much more difficult than they previously had been. It is often very unclear what Dr. G and the TFs are expecting from us, and each grader is very different in what they are looking for.

Strengths are that we get to build on the chemistry information we learned. Weaknesses, this course requires a lot of work and I am not sure if 0.5 credits is equivalent to the amount of work we put in.

Strength: TAs are great
Weaknesses: organization, parallel to actual chemistry course

Dr. G. is a very good instructor and the course is organized to facilitate learning. It could be improved by having a clearer understanding of the expectations of lab reports. Often getting good grades is like a lottery because you accidentally put in information that was relevant. The problem is that there was no teaching that suggested that it was important prior to submitting an assignment.
The labs itself are a lot of busy work that is time consuming where we get the idea while the lab reports take a long time. The grading can also be meticulous.

I enjoyed Dr. G's lectures in the beginning in the class, but I did not find that I learn much from the labs themselves. Much of it seems like busywork that could be improved by implementing shorter, but more thought-provoking, experiments.

If you're taking this class, you're probably only taking it because it's a requirement of sorts. Dr. G is very finicky with grading, and to be frank, this class really deterred me from taking other STEM classes overall. That's how bad of an impression this class left on me. But, you have to get done what needs to get done.

This course is honestly not great. Dr. G's standards for lab reports are somewhat mystifying, as different people lose different amounts of points for putting the same thing on their lab report. There is no rhyme or reason to this class. Sometimes, everyone gets a 100 on the quiz and then he makes the next so impossibly hard that the average is a 15/25. The only good part is that you drop your lowest lab report/quiz score. The only way to improve this is to make it more about students exploring/actually understanding chemistry rather than conforming to Dr. G's patently absurd lab report requirements that in no way reflect one's engagement with the subject.
The TAs should be more consistent on grading

Could be more engaging, less painful to write up reports and be in lab for so long. Sometimes coming out of lab felt unbearable and I lost points on labs even with putting in maximal work for arbitrary things.
I think the emphasis of this course is very poorly placed. There is more focus on pedantic lab reports than the actual learning from experiments. I am not a fan of how it is structured.
I think that the biggest weakness of this course is the workload. It is so much work every week.
The course pre-lecture was always very helpful and the lab TA's were always ready to help if you had any questions in lab.

Strengths: Important information about lab procedures was learned

Weaknesses: Lab reports were often long and required extra work that seemed unnecessary. It was difficult to gauge what the reports wanted and you lose many points in them because of it.

A strength is that Dr. G really cares about the subject and is quite good at explaining chemistry concepts. The weaknesses are that the lab reports are harshly graded and the experience of being in the lab space is rather horrible.

The course can improve if Dr. G wrote the lab manuals in a more understandable and concise manner. For instance, instead of writing in paragraphs filled with stylistic questions and unnecessary precautions, the lab manuals can number the steps in a sequential manner to make the students more effective in the laboratory. Furthermore, students were not instructed about what to write in the objective section of the lab, yet they were responsible for including very specific phrases or lose points on the report. This asymmetrical information caused frustration and confusion during the year even for students who thoroughly understand the course material.
This class was unnecessarily tedious, with the weekly quizzes and long lab reports being the major weaknesses.
The course is horrible and I had to work with a lecturer I had been threatened by in the fall semester.

Strengths: Teaching excel and word
Weaknesses: Chemistry

The greatest strength of this course is the organization. I think the experiments are really organized and efficient in terms of corresponding to the chemistry we are learning. The lab reports were fine, and it was fun doing the experiments. I think I learned a lot of chemistry. I think the weaknesses are if Dr. G was more approachable. He already made this course a lot better than last year. The course would be better if the experiments were less repetitive (i.e. when we had to pipet a ton of solutions for the whole experiment). I wish there were more practice problems for the concepts we were learning because for students in Chem 167, it was sometimes difficult to review and follow what was going on. I also think significant figures could be less emphasized because there are more important concepts in chemistry. Lastly, I wish accuracy was not graded. Still, I learned a lot, and we had it pretty easy compared to last year since there are no finals.

This course is a nightmare. The class is 4 hours every week, and the lab reports take between 6-8 hours to complete if you're completely focused and doing them carefully. You learn very little from the course. The grading is nit-picky and depending on which TF grades your reports, you can lose 10 extra points. The class is stressful and frustrating, and while Dr. G is a good lecturer, it's simply not enough to make up for the amount of busy work he assigns. This is the only class I've taken at Yale that's simply a waste of time, but if you want to do a serious science major you have to take this class.

One of the weaknesses of this course was that grading sometimes felt arbitrary because expectations were not always clear, and some experiments were so logistically complex as to be quite stressful for students with little prior lab experience.
Stop with the quizzes as they are much more difficult than an actual exam question and merely add more stress to an otherwise useless lab that is only required.

This course, for what it was, required a lot of work. Completing the experiments was sometimes a difficult task and along those same lines, there is a bit of inconsistency in grading between TFs. The pre-lab quizzes were extremely challenging this semester and did not seem very fair given the information presented on the lab manual and pre-lab lecture. As an introductory lab course, it surely turned me off from doing anything further in the chemistry department. I am not sure what would have made the course better. That being said, I do think that it covered a great amount of topics in chemistry and certainly taught me important basic lab techniques. I think given a less strict environment, the course could have been both extremely informational, but also enjoyable.

I think some of the labs were repetitive. For example, we did two titration labs and several labs involving spectroscopy which made the class seem somewhat redundant. Also, I always felt underprepared for the lab quizzes because they were on material that wasn't being covered in class, and I felt like the pre lab lectures didn't fully prepare you for the quizzes. Also, I wish that the material taught in my chemistry lecture aligned with the lab. Also, I felt like the grading was somewhat inconsistent. I felt like my grades sometimes depended on the TA that graded my lab.
Some experiments are long for the sake of being long. And also it is unrealistic to be quizzed on topics learned that very same day. Quizzes on new topics should be the week after they are learned.

The lab experiments are very interesting however, the lab reports are ridiculously long and the quizzes are difficult and unfair. The grading of the lab reports is unfair too because you could get the entire concept of the lab correct however you would lose lots of points for minor mistakes like significant figures or not including a word in the purpose section.

Many experiments in this class felt pointless, unnecessarily challenging from a technical perspective (for instance an experiment in which we needed to take temperature measurements that were essentially physically impossible). Lab reports are graded arbitrarily. Lectures are the strongest part of the course- Dr. G happens to be a great teacher even though the class is grueling and beyond frustrating.
The course was good all around, but was a lot of work for a half credit course.

Strengths: using what was taught in chem class in real life
Weaknesses: sometimes more guidance was needed

Strengths- great course content and interesting experiments. My TA was fantastic. 

Weakness- the course felt a lot more stressful than my other classes and I feel as though it should not be that way. It makes learning more difficult.
The lab reports are graded very hard.
Labs are only worth half a credit for a full credit's amount of work.
This is likely the worst class I ave ever taken at Yale. The grading rubric is petty and marks are frequently lost for trivial reasons that have nothing to do with science or formatting.
weakness: grading on the lab reports is almost entirely based on which TA is grading it.
Please give us more information on the material that will be covered on the pre-lab quizzes.

Strengths: 
- Gives students a thorough understanding of chemistry topics and chemistry in practice

Weaknesses: 
- Such emphasis is placed on perfection that many students fake their results (change numbers, e.g.) in order to obtain a desired grade
I think there was a lack of clarity on how the lab reports were graded, and the quizzes reflected more of previous knowledge students had than what was taught in lecture.

I think that this course has both strengths and weaknesses. Some of the strengths of this course are that the chemistry is so in depth that you are forced to learn/understand many concepts of chemistry. This was a strength for me because it helped me in my general chemistry course. Some of the weaknesses were the quizzes and graders. The grading on the lab reports was never consistent and the quizzes seemed much more challenging than the material the course lent itself to.

The strength of this course is that it helps you learn the basics of chemistry and directly ties to what is being learned in general chemistry. The weakness of this course is the grading on the lab reports are too strict and unclear, and it is hard to tell if you will get a good grade on the lab reports.
The reports are way to long and intense for a lab.
I feel that I learned a lot about the chemistry behind this course, as well as how to use the lab instruments correctly. However, I felt that this class was very formulaic and lacked interest.
It was harsh and inflexible in its teaching manners. The work demand for a good grade was also high, which I believe hurt some students.
Strengths: detailed lab reports, good/timely feedback.

This course taught more basic chemistry principles, but it suffers from many of the same drawbacks as 134L namely, absurdly long lab reports and quizzes that don't really reflect the topics/knowledge of the course. Grading was also really inconsistent and arbitraryfrom what I understand, Dr. G makes a rubric that the TAs follow, but the rubrics often seem random and they are differentially applied from grader to grader.
specific TAs grades unfairly
It did reinforce concepts from Chem 165 really well

A strength that this class has is the TA's. They are very helpful and willing to make sure that you understand the lab that you are doing. This class has many weaknesses. It is an incredible amount of work for a half credit and I would say it was my most stressful and heaviest work load out of all my classes this semester.

I feel that the course taught me nothing and only brought upon unnecessary stress. The grading of lab reports is completely arbitrary, and I never felt that I knew what do with my report to get a good grade. In other words, it was not evident what our task was with the reports. In one of the labs, I was even deducted many points for poor data. I don't feel that I was at fault for the poor data, as the instruments we were given to use did not work properly, and even my TA told me that they are bad and not to worry about it. I also felt that the instructions for the lab were not great, and I was often confused as to what I was supposed to be doing in the lab.
The actual lab course was really great, but the prelab lectures and prelab quizzes were absolutely terrible. If a better more understanding person taught this it would be so much better

Strengths: Dr. G is a pretty good lecturer and he always explains the procedures clearly. Sometimes the labs also help us understand concepts in lecture too, like electrochem, but usually not if you're taking 167.

Weaknesses: The grading, but that's hard to change -- and from what I've heard the grading is already easier than in years' past.

The course itself was okay, but I didn't feel like classroom time was effective enough. Things were not clearly explained, and I didn't like how I had to attend office hours to have things explained to me when the class time wasn't used effectively. A lot of the time I didn't understand what was being looked for in the lab reports, and scheduling office hours so many times seemed like I was doing a lot of work just for a 0.5 credit class.
IT SHOULD NOT BE WORTH JUST HALF A CREDIT, IT IS MORE WORK THAN SOME OF MY OTHER CLASSES THAT ARE ONE CREDIT.
I definitely learned a lot of theoretical and experimental chemistry from the course. One weakness was that lab report grading was sometimes ambiguous and confusing.
The quizzes sucked & the lab reports & labs werent very interesting.
The course exposed me to a wide variety of laboratory procedures. However, the labs were often long for the given time period.
Grading could be improved

Chemistry 136L seemed much more poorly organized than the first semester of this course in that the material we were covering in lab did not match up with the material being taught in chem 165. Given that the classes are supposed to go together, I think it was unfair to give quizzes on concepts taught months before, especially given that success on the quizzes required memorization of formulas that we had not been required to memorize in the first place for the normal general chemistry course. Additionally, doing well on the lab reports was not contingent on understanding the concepts behind the lab, and instead had to do with following minute formatting details.

The weakness is that there is a heavy emphasis on grades and so there is a lot of pressure out on one self to study for weekly quizzes and to work for hours at a time on lab reports and this often manifests (at least in my peers) in anger and frustration.

Strengths: The experiments are colorful and really help to solidify the knowledge that we are learning in CHEM 165 lecture.  
Weakness: Some of the experiments were very difficult to complete in a timely manner and did not necessarily introduce a new concept.  For example, one experiment used a spectrophotometer  and thermocouple temperature sensor and it was very difficult to complete the task properly.
Dr. G gives clear prelab lectures and is willing to help you if you reach out and is clearly passionate about the subjecy
One strength is that it teaches you to pay attention to the small details. The weaknesses far outweigh the strengths. The course is overly strict to students and grading is incredibly harsh.

This course is unnecessarily stressful and sucks all of the enjoyment I once had for chemistry lab. This wasn't because the lab day itself was bad, but because the grading for this course is so erratic and inconsistent, none of the work you do is ever evaluated fairly. It leaves one wondering what the point of learning the content is when you will often be unfairly graded. Furthermore, any efforts to rectify this issue only results in more points lost as though you are being punished for asking questions about the course and your lab report.

It's fine, it's just often boring because you're doing experiments and things that have already been done and proved, and have little relevance to real scientific studies. Most of the labs are fine, but some are a little difficult and chaotic and long.
I believe quizes are unnecessary.
A strength is that it pushes you to organize your time and be careful/meticulous while doing work. A weakness is that it is very demanding, sometimes unreasonably.
Dr.G is great.

My strengths were that when we did the problem sets, I was able to work with my classmates to get the correct answers.  Wy weaknesses were studying for the test and that could be improved be giving the students a study guide.

The labs were very useful and correlated with the material learned during the class. The only suggestion I have is to return the submitted lab reports with feedback a little bit earlier so students can use the feedback to improve their next lab report.
The balance in workload was not very stable. I think long and arduous labs should be strategically positioned and planned so we don't end up getting stressed out in those weeks.
Quizzes were too difficult to do with the amount of time allotted.
Grading is unrealistically harsh. everyone taking this course is doing so for a program down the line that requires good grades. this course just screws us all over.
There are no strengths. Spend an inordinate amount of time learning nothing for half of a credit. The class firstly should be a full credit and secondly taught by someone new
More direction should be provided for the lab reports. They are often way too long and complicated.
I wish we could design our own experiments using concepts from gen chem.
Strengths include making students even more disciplined and attentive to small details. Weaknesses is your grade suffers!

The course could be improved by not having as dense of a curriculum because lab reports become more about getting through tedious information rather than learning the concepts conducted in the experiments. A strength of this class was the availability of teaching assistants to help us through labs and their reports during times that were not their office hours.

This course does well to teach us how to apply our chemistry knowledge in a lab. But the grading of lab reports and the strictness which they are grading its a little much. Points would be taken off for the littlest of things, things that do not show we aren't capable and knowledgable about chemistry.
It can be improved with less emphasis on small details for lab reports.

I didn't like this course very much, the workload was not worth only half a credit and the grading was very specific, so it was hard to do very well in this class. However, it was a good introduction into the basics of research in a chem lab and helped me write very thorough lab reports.

A strength of the course is that it is challenging. It really pushes you to understand the underlying principles of the chemistry used in the experiments. There aren't any weaknesses in the course. It is only a weakness if you underestimate the amount of attention the course needs. Proficiency in Microsoft Word is necessary if you want to excel at the lab reports.

Strengths: Learned a lot of information and chemistry that we were able to observe firsthand, and connected well with the material in the course CHEM165.
Weaknesses: A lot of the skills we used were very repetitive especially in comparison to last semester -- many of the labs involved the same skills like titration and spectrophotometry and I didn't feel like I learned how to use very much new equipment or developed any new lab skills.
The labs were often interesting. However, some of them were extremely long, which made finishing them a time crunch.

I felt that the pre-lab lectures went on for far too long. They would sometimes last for an hour. The lectures were oftentimes unnecessary given that most of us were in (or had already taken) the corresponding general chemistry course. There was no need for us to be retaught the information, especially in such an inefficient way.

Dr. G clearly had a lot enthusiasm for the course and subject.

The grading was unnecessarily harsh.
Strengths were the level of hands-on practice and engagement we had. Weakness was the grading system and how our lab reports were graded.

Strengths: Learning how to work together with others in a high-stress environment. Most of the people in CHEM 136L are competitive premed students, and it was constantly a competition to see who would leave the lab first. It allowed me to become more cutthroat.

Weaknesses: How can the purposes of lab reports be less than 150 words long and still expect people to include all the relevant details?

While I actually thought the labs themselves were quite interesting, and some of the TAs helpful, the strengths end there. The lab is one of the poorest run and taught classes I have ever taken - I did many of the labs in high school and got much more out of those than I did from these. At the beginning of each lab we would have a quiz on the upcoming lab. Though rather than asking thought-provoking questions, the quizzes contained random questions from things tangentially related to the lab or were dull memorization questions such as "what substances are we using in the lab." The lab reports were worse. Not once were we tasked with conducting a thoughtful scientific analysis of the experiment or even asked scientifically interesting questions. Instead, reports consisted of three questions whose answers were copied straight from the manual and a plethora of graphs to make and equations to transcribe. While I understand the necessity of constructing graphs, I don't understand why huge amounts of points are deducted for creating accurate and useful figures that don't align with the arbitrary standards set forth by Dr. G. You essentially are graded on your ability to create graphs and write equations rather than your ability to analyze an experiment. Furthermore, the TAs graded arbitrarily, some taking off seemingly excessive points for questionable formatting errors while others didn't for the same mistake. They'd be better off asking interesting questions and doing away with the tedious busy work. Dr. G's conduct was also questionable, as his default reaction when someone is having trouble was to accuse them of being sloppy and not caring at an excessive volume. I witnessed several incidents where after said tongue-lashing, the equipment turned out to be faulty (after attempting to do the experiment himself, he couldn't achieve the correct result himself). Evidently, no one wanted to ask him for help in order to avoid such situations. To his credit, it is clear Dr. G cares about the lab and chemistry in general, but in its current form, I'm not sure anyone would take the course unless required to. The thing that troubles me most about the class is that all of the concerns I raised have been raised before (on OCE) over many years yet nothing has changed and probably won't. Yale has stated that one of its focuses is to improve its STEM departments and attract more science oriented majors, yet they continue to allow this class to be the first experience many students have with collegiate level science. If the goal was to deter students from pursuing science majors, this class is perfect as is. I'm not sure what the point of course evaluations are if a class that is unavoidable (required for most science majors and pre-med), an introduction to a field (sciences in general), and has been evaluated negatively in the same way year after year fails to change at all following the feedback. It would be a mistake to continue allowing the course to be taught in such a way. If Yale really cares about promoting STEM on campus, they can't continue to allow this to be students' first exposure to it.

This course does a good job of reinforcing the concurrent lecture's material and exposing students to lab techniques. The labs themselves are generally pretty interesting, save a few tedious, boring ones. The TAs work very hard and range from decently to extremely helpful, depending on the TA. 

The grading of this course is ridiculously and unnecessarily harsh. The lab quizzes are often overly difficult or too long to complete in the 15 minute time frame. The grading of the lab reports is nitpicky, and we never know what we are expected to have until we get our report grades back. The lab reports also felt pointless, since we were just filling in the blanks and trying to figure out what Dr. G wanted from us, not actually analyzing the results (i.e. difficult grading rubric and grading on accuracy).

The content that were are tested on in our weekly quizzes could be better explained. Also, practice quizzes could be shared with students to help them better prepare. Lab reports are graded and released to students in a fairly well schedule. More resources and clarity on how to better improve should be available to students.
More transparency on how the course is graded and reasonable requirements for purposes.

Strengths: Relevant material, interesting labs, helpful and informative Was
Weaknesses: Weekly quizzes

extremely time consuming class. I really liked the prelab lectures they are very helpful although the quizzes were hard to prepare for, this was not clearly outlined. I felt the quizzes tested how well you understood the material from the prelab lecture directly before. there was no time for preparation. this was challenging since the material was not hard but the timing of the quiz was problematic since it was impossible to really prepare. the quizzes were also weighted to heavily in the final grade. Dr. G was a good lecturer and explained concepts well, only the quizzes were problematic. TF marking was also very ambiguous and inconsistent.

Strengths: lab techniques and requirement of class
Weakness: lab quizzes are unnecessarily stressful and grades are not given out evenly for a curved classroom
I thought that having a predictable schedule was helpful, but sometimes the grading of lab reports was inconsistent.

Not much was learned in terms of chemistry. It is too much attention placed on insignificant details, and not that much placed on the actual chemistry content. I was losing 3-4 points on every lab report on the purpose without ever receiving clear feedback on what should be included.

Aside from the STEM department being terrible, this course was way too difficult to be considered a lab course: the amount of things we had to do in lab were a lot. I had to do nearly 4 completely different experiments every week: twice I had to come back into the lab to continue because I either didn't finish or I had too large a percent error because I was being rushed the entire time. The only strength was being able to talk about the lab reports with your friends so that you didn't feel alone in doing half of the lab report, and realized you formatted your graphs wrongly. One BIG weakness is that this class meets for more time than any other class, but is only 0.5 credits: although the lab reports are not comparable to PSET's in difficulty, the time taken away from my classes for that day of lab should be factored into the credit value. I do no spend 4 hours of painstaking lab work and 2 hours of lab report writing (plus 2 more because you make mistakes) to only get a measly 0.5 credits.

The course is a comprehensive introduction to lab practices and it manages to walk students through a lot of different lab techniques during the semester. Nonetheless, I believe that as a student of CHEM 167 this lab course was completely disjointed from what I was taught in my introductory chemistry lecture course. There was no clear connection between the topics taught in CHEM 167 as opposed to the intimate connection that existed between the topics of CHEM 134L and CHEM 165. This may have made the lab course seem pointless at times, as it did not build upon the concepts that were taught in lecture in order to analyze in an empirical context. Another weakness of the course was for me the way in which the lab reports were graded. And by saying that, I do not purely mean the way in which points were deducted from the lab reports; rather, I focus on the fact that the lab reports were corrected slowly, not allowing for improvement in a student's work. More specifically, the lab reports were returned to us corrected two weeks after we submitted them. Bearing in mind that a lab report was due on a weekly basis, it was many times the case that the mistakes that were made on one report were repeated on the next one, as the students were unable to identify their mistakes and correct them promptly. Furthermore, the many times excessive focus on detail caused frustration in the students and created a tense relation with the lab course that was unnecessary. Another frustrating aspect of the course, were definitely the pre-lab quizzes. I believe that the quizzes had no other aim other than purely testing how good a student was at retaining the information that was taught in the pre-lab lecture for several minutes and reproducing them at a ridiculous speed in the quiz. Especially this semester, the quizzes were extremely packed with problems and it was many times almost impossible for the students to finish them. I felt that my performance in the quizzes was hurt because of this excessive lack of time.  All in all, although the course was a thorough introduction to lab practices, I believe that it is necessary that some of its weaknesses are corrected in order for it to be a more effective in its aim.

The course is a lot of work for being only half a credit. The amount of time and work that goes into it is much more than some other full credit classes. However, the material is interesting and the labs are engaging. I do wish that the class followed the pacing of material in the General Chemistry class to fully help connect the concepts learned in class to the lab.

Strength: Great TAs (love you Dave) 

Weakness: quizzes were unnecessarily difficult, it's kinda ridiculous to expect us to memorize formulas to use on the quizzes, the labs were very long and tedious and I didn't learn a thing standing there for hours doing titrations, also the degree to which lab reports are scrutinized is extremely unnecessary- even if you spend hours working on the report a week (which you will do because the shortest one still took 2.5hours while the longest was easily over 6 hours of work) you're likely to get dinged multiple times for ridiculous reasons

Strengths: instructor was pretty solid at explaining things 

Weakness: lab reports unnecessarily difficult, lab procedures often painful and annoying, instructor sometimes rude

This course truly helps students to learn basic chemistry laboratory techniques. However, at the same time the class grading system is often overly harsh in a way that only frustrates students but does not aid in learning.
Weakness: quizzes

It is a good way to learn a lot of chemistry methods. Grading is very nit-picky; a lot of points will be taken off for things not in lab reports that were mentioned extremely briefly during lab. Also the quizzes are not really effective ways to test what we know since we are quizzed on information we are expected to memorize literally 15 min before we take the quiz, with no time to practice/apply the information. Do not have enough time for taking the quizzes.
It certainly provides students with a solid exposure to the basics of lab design and implementation. It is, however, far heavier a workload than 0.5 credits.
Some labs we did felt pointless. Once, we had a lab in which we put a thermometer in a cuvette that was IN  a spectrophotometer. Collecting data was often tedious and difficult.

No strengths. It seems intentionally designed to be a pre-med weedout thats painful to take. None of the material is interesting or novel, all of the experiments are like watching paint dry, and the lab reports are tedious at best. Grading on the lab reports is unnecessarily strict (particularly in regards to the purpose/methods section), and the quizzes are unnecessarily difficult. On top of all of this, 1.0 credit workload for a half credit.
This course is fine except for the difficulty level.  For an introductory course, it is graded extremely strictly.

The labs were extremely tedious; most of them were very long. The best part about the course was that coincided very well with the lecture course (CHEM 165). The lab quizzes were quite hard and stressful, although a lot of them drew from the "Calculations" sections of the lab manuals. I felt like the main weakness of the course was just that nobody cared about anything--the course is so big that I was just falling through the cracks. Nobody wants to go to lab or learn--not even the TAs. I just didn't feel like it was a good learning environment. Dr. G is a great teacher and is quite approachable, but he doesn't reach out very warmly to his students.

I think the class could be 100% fair-er if the things that students are required to know/put on the lab reports were made clearer. There's almost no way to predict what one will lose points on or to not lose points (or to gain bonus points) because feedback is not consistent and TAs aren't allowed to check reports before they are submitted. There's almost no reason to keep this information from students who just want to improve. I think that's the main complaint most people have--the class itself is structured fine, but the method of point-giving/removing is somewhat ridiculous.

The strengths of this course included making the laboratory available to students to learn essential skills and that the labs helped students learn more about different concepts in chemistry. The course's weakness was primarily the professor. The professor was unwelcoming and intimidating to students, making it difficult to ask questions and enjoy the course material. Furthermore, lab report feedback was sent out late and students were unable to see their previous mistakes on similar labs to move towards an improved lab report grade.
I think that the weekly quizzes and lab reports were a weakness of the class. I know that they are needed considering this was a lab course, but they did not help facilitate learning in any way.

The course was organized in that we knew what to expect for each week: there was always a quiz and a lab report to write up. Similar to last semester, I feel that the grading is still very much unfair (although I think it is better than last semester) because different TAs would grade things differently. Some graded more harshly than others.

Strengths: the TAs are super nice and helpful. 
Weaknesses: The grading is very harsh and somewhat seemingly arbitrary. The quizzes are unnecessarily difficult. The lab reports are very tedious.

A strength was that the course really prepares you to do any lab at Yale. Some weaknesses were that it takes up a great deal of time to be in lab and also write your lab reports. It should be more than a 1/2 credit because it meets for more time than a regular class and we have quizzes and reports due every week.

lab is much too long and would be better as a 3 hour instead of 4 hour course. the problem is that the teacher packs in too much stuff into the labs which makes students lose engagement quickly, since they are long, tiring, and overwhelming. we could definitely learn everything thats important in a shorter course and might actually benefit more. also, we don't get much recourses or time to study for quizzes or learn from past mistakes, since it moves so quickly. maybe instead of 1 quiz per week, a quiz every other week so that each week doesn't just feel like you are plowing through to make it to the next obstacle.

A huge weakness of this course is that we do not receive the previous weeks lab reports back in time in order to apply the changes/corrections to the current weeks lab reports. Also, some of the questions on the lab quizzes are unnecessarily difficult and often the quizzes have to be completed under a time constraint. The only thing good about 136L were the TAs this semester. They were very helpful.

Strengths: Interesting labs
Weaknesses: Strict grading policy and no curve
Not a lot of explaining, not really conducive to actually ;learning whats going on, you just kinda follow the instructions just in order to finish experiments

Weaknesses: Arbitrarily random labs and requirements at times, but more so when you have to do super long lab reports on these it gets frustrating. Just truly twice the work half the credit. 

Strength: Dr. G gives good pre lab lectures that help with the quizzes. He answers lots of questions.

Strengths: the lectures were relatively well-organized, and the TAs were helpful in lab and timely in responding to concerns over email.

Weaknesses: 

The way this course was organized was almost as if it were designed to squash out any pre-existing interest in chemistry that a student may have had. 

The grading scheme in this course was focused on penalizing arbitrary missteps rather than rewarding correct analysis. The weekly quizzes focused predominantly on rote memorization of facts such as chemical formulas and were often unrelated to the material presented in the preceding lecture. The lab reports, which constituted the majority of the grade for this course, were assessed by starting at a perfect score, and then subtracting points for errors that were designated in a hidden rubric. These weekly lab reports typically took several hours to complete, not because there was any intellectual challenge but simply because they were made unnecessarily tedious. Lab reports often required us to type up in Microsoft Word several pages of calculations so we could show our work when the calculations being done were common knowledge in the class by that point. Moreover, many of the labs had an accuracy grade, which was completely ridiculous - oftentimes the lab equipment would be faulty, but we would be forced to repeat the procedure regardless. In addition, the lab reports were mostly graded by a different teaching fellow each week, and it appeared as though each had their own opinions and level of detail that was required. Because of this, I was unable to receive consistent feedback and attempt any long-term improvement.

Overall, the course encourages an extremely unhealthy attitude towards avoiding mistakes, which I believe to be completely unrepresentative of what experimental science actually is in real life. The unreasonable demands of this class compelled many of my classmates to commit dishonest acts in misrepresentation/falsification of data, cover up accidents made in the lab, and copy off one another because they were afraid of the harsh consequences of this class.

The primary weakness is that we learn nothing and that the primary focus of the course is to do frivolous calculations and then proceed to lose points for improper sig figs and mislabeled graphs. I would prefer if I had actually learned something of value in this course.

The class was well structured. I learned a great deal about experimental procedure and chemistry as a subject. However, I believe that the class should be worth more than 0.5 credits because of the workload.
The curve kind of sucks

Some of the experiments in this course are a little long to get done in under three hours, which encourages rushing, which leads to mistakes and safety hazards as we desperately attempt to fish before the class ends.

strengths: covered a broad range of topics, experiments manageable in the time given, provided a different perspective on some chemistry topics from what was seen in lecture (I preferred some methods taught in this class to those taught in lecture), helped me make new friends in chemistry, diversity in teaching staff
weaknesses: some teaching assistant difficult to approach or rude, I often felt unprepared for quizzes whether I studied or not
Bad course.
The lab was very long and sometimes repetitive.
Horrible quizzes. So much effort for nothing. Labs are long but not hard. Takes forever to complete lab report and the TAs are so quick to take off points.

Strengths - Students can learn basic chemistry lab skills and methods. The assignments and due dates are clearly communicated and there is no final which is huge.

Weaknesses- Much of the class does not actually improve students' understanding of chemical concepts and instead seems like rather arbitrary busy work. In addition, the lab reports are graded harshly, and it is often very difficult to predict what will make you lose points or what you did incorrectly. The pre lab quizzes often do not cover the material relevant to the experiment of the day. They also often do not follow the study guide given in the lab manual, making it very difficult to prepare for them. In addition, this class is only a half credit but is more work than many 1 credit classes.
Arbitrary and inconsistent grading that did not reflect how well the experiment was completed and the quality of results. Quizzes were frustrating and unnecessary.

A strength of this course is that the instructor does all he can to lay out all we have to do, so we simply have to follow the instructions well. In addition, Dr. G and your TF do try to help you during the lab and answer all of your questions to ensure everything goes smoothly. A major weakness of this course in inconsistency. No matter how detailed the rubric may be, there are always inconsistencies in the grading because there are different people grading the same thing, and there can be a lot of room for error. It is a hard problem to solve, but I believe going over what point value is what many people get upset about. The quizzes were also inordinately hard, that if you weren't taking Gen Chem 165, you might not know what is going on. There was one quiz where, if I hadn't reviewed the subject beforehand, I certainly would have failed. I think the quizzes should be tailored to the lecture and/or manual, rather than the subject, because not everyone is taking the lecture concurrently.
Do not take this class unless you have to take lab.
Yes, Dr. G is a great teacher and really cares about his students.
No. Never in my wildest dreams.
I would reccomend this course to another student as I found it to be quite fun and engaging. This is a great class for students who want to learn more about chemistry in a lab setting.

I would not recommend this course to another student. The only reason I took this class was because it was required for pre-med, but if you are not a pre-med student, I would stay away from this course. It is only 0.5 credits and it accounted for a large majority of my homework, even when I was taking 5 total credits.
not unless its required for your major.

I would recommend this course because I did learn essential lab skills as well as further my knowledge of chemistry. However, it does require quite a bit of time and effort. That being said, the labs are often fun and if you're smart about them, you can often leave early.
Yes, I would recommend this course to any pre-medical student.
Recommended if you are pre-med or interested in getting exposure to a lab.

I would recommend it to a student who is pre-med or needs to take chemistry lab as a requirement, or to a student who likes doing experiments and writing up lab reports and wants an introduction to lab.
You probably have to take this course. This year, it was much more manageable than what I've heard happen in past years.

This question is useless. Everyone taking this class does it because they have to. Definitely don't take this class if you don't need it for your major or other requirements, but I don't think you should let one class, no matter how terrible, deter you from pursuing a career in your interest.
Yes, it's a prerequisite.
only if pre med.
I would recommend this course, with the stipulation that the student must enjoy chemistry and lab work to do well.
No I would not. This course feels like it's in place to discourage everyone from becoming a bio major.
Yes, I would recommend this course only because it helped me understand the concepts from gen chem lecture and helped me gain basic laboratory skills.
No. Worst class I've taken at Yale.

Most students are taking this as a requirement. If you have the choice, though, why would you voluntarily spend 4 hours every week doing lab and many more hours every week writing a lab report? It's a huge time commitment.
No, it is a terrible course but unfortunately an unavoidable one

The course is a lot of work, especially for only half a credit.  It definitely helps with Chem 165 concepts, and so if you're taking the lecture class, it's not a bad idea to take lab with it, but also it is a lot of work if you don't have to do it for a requirement.

I wouldn't recommend it if they weren't already required to take it for their major or for the pre-med track. There wouldn't be any reason for them to take it and despite being only half a credit, it does have a relatively high workload.

Only if you have to take it. Not necessarily a reflection of the teaching but a reflection of the course design, it takes up a good amount of time and lab write ups take a while, if you want to do well it also requires that you invest time into regularly going to office hours. A fine course overall though
No - you really don't learn much and it's too much work for the amount of learning that actually happens
no, but if you have to take it, you just have to.

Not one bit, but you likely have to take it for your major so just stick it out. My advice: don't stress about this class more than it's worth. I had friends who would spend 12+ hours per week perfecting the lab reports just to pull an A-. I would put in 3, maybe 4 hours and get a B+, and you know what? That was the right decision. A B+ in gen chem lab will NOT be the reason you don't get into grad/med school, so don't worry about this class more than it warrants. You'll save yourself the inevitable pain and shame you get when you get a random 70 on a lab report for no apparent reason. Listen, it's not a reflection you or your understanding of chemistry. Doing well in gen chem does not mean you will do well in gen chem lab, and vice versa, because this class tests your ability to conform to arbitrary requirements rather than your engagement and ability with chemistry. It sounds terrible, and it is, but it's way less terrible if you just acknowledge that the class is dumb and stop stressing about it. Work on your grades and other classes to make up for this one, because normal classes have a direct correlation between effort put in and your grade, whereas this has no such relationship.

Not if you do not need it. General Chemistry Lab demands a lot of work and preparation, so if you do not need it, or do not have the time and energy for it, do not take it. Lab reports take hours, and you need a good hour to adequately prepare for the lab each week. In addition, your experience (and grade) can vary depending on what TA you receive, what partner you work with, and simply luck in terms of results.
